title: Your new Cape house could be a 245-square-foot cottage in Eastham for $259,000
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: A 245-square-foot cottage in Eastham, built in 1940, is listed for $259,000.
The cottage features a one-bed, one-bath layout with pine floors and rustic beamed ceilings.
Located in Cottage Grove, Eastham, the $135 quarterly HOA fee covers amenities near the National Seashore.

title: A Newburyport teen’s body was unidentified for 33 years. Now, his aunt and a cold-case aficionado want to bring him home.
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Anthony Angelli Rea, missing since 1988 from Newbury's Harbor School, was identified after 33 years through DNA testing.
Maya Ambrose, intrigued by Rea's case since her teens, helped connect Rea's aunt, Carolann Angelli, to his remains.
A GoFundMe, launched by Ambrose, raised funds to bury Rea alongside his family after being unidentified for decades.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com launched a news quiz featuring topics like Hasbro and public figures Matt Damon and Ben Affleck.
The quiz covers trending stories from the Greater Boston area, including developments involving Arthur T. Demoulas.
AI technology contributed to creating questions for the quiz, available on Boston.com as of September 12, 2025.

title: Amid opt-out rumors, Sam Kennedy says Alex Bregman ‘wants to be here’ with Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Alex Bregman could opt out of his Red Sox contract after the 2025 season to test free agency.
Sam Kennedy stated on WEEI that both the Red Sox and Bregman want him to stay with the team.
Bregman has performed well with a .279 average, 16 home runs, and 57 RBI over 101 games this season.

title: Bill Belichick says in new book that Tom Brady made ‘right decision’ to leave Patriots in 2020
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick acknowledges in a new book that Tom Brady made the right decision to leave the Patriots in 2020.
Belichick cited the Patriots' inability to build a competitive team around Brady due to salary cap constraints.
Brady eventually led the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to a Super Bowl win after leaving the Patriots in 2020.

title: West Boylston town administrator fired after Trump flag dispute sues town
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: James Ryan, former West Boylston town administrator, sues the town for $1.3 million alleging wrongful termination.
Ryan was fired after a dispute with Police Chief Dennis Minnich over a Trump flag at the police department.
Ryan claims his termination was retaliation for enforcing town by-laws and ethics laws on political activity.

title: 18-year-old injured in R.I. after lighting himself on fire for TikTok challenge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: An 18-year-old man was hospitalized with severe burns in North Smithfield, R.I., after a TikTok challenge went wrong.
The challenge involved pouring gasoline, lighting themselves on fire, and jumping off a trestle into Slatersville Reservoir.
A 16-year-old accompanied the man but was unharmed; the incident was inspired by a video seen on Instagram.

title: ‘Fear and uncertainty’: Everett officials cancel Hispanic Heritage Month festival amid ICE crackdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Everett officials canceled Fiesta Del Rio, set for Sept. 20, due to recent ICE raids in the area.
The event was to be held at Rivergreen Park, celebrating Hispanic culture with music, art, and local vendors.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria cited community fear and uncertainty as reasons for canceling the fourth annual festival.

title: Josh Kraft ends mayoral campaign after coming in second by nearly 50 points in Tuesday’s preliminary
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Josh Kraft ends his Boston mayoral campaign after losing to Mayor Michelle Wu by nearly 50 points in the preliminary.
Kraft raised over $6.8 million for his campaign, using $5.5 million of his own funds, compared to Wu's $1.8 million.
He plans to donate $3 million to address the humanitarian crisis in Boston after suspending his campaign.

title: Josh McDaniels defends Drake Maye: ‘He’s the right guy’ for Patriots
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Josh McDaniels defends Drake Maye, emphasizing a long-term vision for his development with the Patriots.
Drake Maye faced criticism after the Patriots' Week 1 loss, struggling particularly in the second half against the Raiders.
McDaniels denies overloading Maye with information, highlighting his natural learning curve with the Patriots' offensive system.
